titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. First meeting of the Commissioners in the case of John W. Blanchard at 9 this morning— Attended afterwards in the Senate— At 12 o’clock the governor came and delivered his speech to the two houses; after which Mr: Ames was qualified as a counsellor— The Speech opens no prospect of business for the legislature— Nothing of material importance was done— At 5 o’clock in the afternoon I went to Mr: Gill’s; where I met Mr: Sullivan, and Mr: Smith, and we spent a couple of hours in endeavouring to make a settlement of the demand of John Boylston’s trustees, upon Mr: Gill’s estate— We made some progress to a settlement, but parted, leaving it still very dubious.— I presented in Senate this afternoon a petition from a part of the town of Weymouth, to be incorporated as a town— A former petition had been referr’d over from the last Session; and the papers with it, could not now be found— So the petition lies for the present.— I spent the evening at home.

2. Attended in the Senate— Began with a Committee for considering the expediency of appointing a reporter— I utterly disagreed with Mr: Bidwell and Mr: Morton upon the principles which should govern the establishment of such an Officer— Mr: Bradbury agreed with me— Lowell was not there— At 11. the Senate met— Had no business of material consequence in the forenoon— At 3. p.m. we met again— And at 1/2 past 3 in Convention of the two houses, for the choice of Secretary, Treasurer and Notaries public— Mr: Hayward was first qualified as a Counsellor— Then Mr: Avery was rechosen Secretary— Mr: Jackson was elected as Treasurer; an Office vacant by the Constitution, Mr Coffin having served the five years allowed for the same person to hold the office in succession— The notaries for the most part were rechosen. Warren and another Plymouth man, endeavoured by a trick to turn out one of the best men in Plymouth County, but did not succeed— We were engaged in this work till about 7. o’clock— The Senate then return’d to their hall, and soon after adjourn’d— I came home and walk’d out with Mrs: Adams— We look’d over a new house near Beacon hill— Remainder of the Evening at Club, at Judge Dawes’s— It was not numerous— My mother came and dined in town— Louisa Smith went home with her.

3. I had engaged to dine this day with Mr: S. Elliot, but as the report of the Senate’s Committee upon the Answer to the Governor’s speech was to be made at 4 o’clock this afternoon, I was obliged to send him an excuse. We had no business of consequence in Senate this forenoon— But in the afternoon, the report of the Committee was made and read. It was very offensive to the other side of the house— Mr: Pickman who drew the answer, had at my request, and in full concurrence with his own opinion inserted a clause declaring that for the support of the Constitution we consider it as most essential that the independence of the judiciary department should remain inviolate— This was the clause which roused the party in arms— They affected to take it up with extraordinary solemnity moved for a distant time to debate it, and General Hull moved that a number of copies should be printed for the use of its the members.— I saw this as a menace, and therefore supported the motion— The thing was altogether unprecedented, and it was intended as a threat of appeal to the people: the only way to meet it was with defiance— General Hull withdrew his motion, for he found his own party more averse to it than ours— We assign’d to-morrow afternoon to debate the Answer— Evening at home.

4. Mr: Simpkins, a Minister in the town of Harwich called upon me this morning, respecting a petition of part of that town for a division, which by a mistake in counting the numbers yesterday upon a vote of the Senate, was rejected— He made me a statement of facts, and ask’d for my support to obtain a reconsideration of the vote— In the forenoon the bill to secure a full representation of the people of this Commonwealth in Congress, which I had drawn up, and Mr: Bidwell reported, was read for the first time— Bidwell opposed it— Next Tuesday was assigned for the second reading.— In the afternoon the Answer to the Governor’s speech was debated for more than three hours. Various attempts were made to strike out, to defeat, and to neutralize the clause respecting the independence of the judiciary. Every modification on our part was offered and inserted as to the form of expressions, but as to the sentiment itself we insisted upon the propriety and expediency of its insertion— The votes for it were 19 to 11.— But Mr: Thomson the Senator from Plymouth voted very reluctantly with us, and under great fear and trembling, for the consequences— He begg’d at first to be excused from voting, and finally said he should have liked much better to have the clause expung’d— And he hoped no body would be offended at his requesting to be excused from voting— The President told him, by all means; and that whenever he had such a wish the Senate would always be willing to indulge him in it— We adjourn’d at about 8 in the evening. Walk’d afterwards with Quincy— We call’d at Dr: Jackson’s, but found nobody there— Walk’d again in the Mall.

5. Opened a Commission of bankruptcy, against Amos Blanchard, at 9. this morning— Took the oaths of office, before the Governor and two Members of the Council, as a Justice of the Peace and Quorum for the County of Suffolk— There were no fees, but 2. dollars must be paid to the County treasurer, as excise— I attended upon a Committee with Mr: Hichborn and Mr: Hunnewell, on the petition of Mr: Vinall— We could not hear him through; as Mr: Hunnewell was called to the house— The Senate had before them a petition from Gilbert Dench which he had leave to withdraw, and a petition for a second Bank in Portland which was discuss’d only in part. Adjourn’d till Tuesday morning.— Dined at Mr: Parkman’s, with a large company of Gentlemen. Among them, the Governor and lieutenant Governor, General Lee, Mr: Mason, Mr: Dexter &c. In the afternoon I came out to Quincy, with W. Shaw.

6. Heard Mr: Popkin— He dined with us.— Bathed, between 4 and 5 this morning— Spent an hour this evening at Mr: Cranch’s.— Read Plutarch’s treatise upon the manner of reading the poets—in Amyot’s french translation.

7. Return’d to Boston this morning with my father; and W. Shaw.— At the bankrupt-office— Went to hear the artillery election sermon; which was preach’d by Mr: Abiel Abbot, my uncle Shaw’s successor at Haverhill—but not my classmate— Thence went to the dinner at Faneuil-Hall. B. Russell the printer was Captain of the ancient and honourable artillery company, which held this anniversary; and he made the toasts; some of which were good— About 4. o’clock the company broke up for the performance of the ceremonies in investing the new Captain for the year, with his insignia— I first went to the Commissioners’ Office, where we had a third meeting for Ichabod Frost, and two of us opened a new Commission— Came home, but found Mrs: Adams gone out. Went and found her at the State-house. We went into the Senate chamber, and thence saw the exhibition of the day— Return’d and spent the evening at home— Received a letter from my brother, enclosing one from Mr: Pitcairn.

8. At the Commissioners Office— 3d: meeting for W. Neal. At 4. in the afternoon— The Remainder of the day at the Senate— Forenoon debate upon the bill for amending the Districting Law— Recommitted at noon for a new Section— Afternoon debate on a petition for a new bank at Portland— Eveg: at home.

9. Attended at the Senate, upon two Committees before the meeting of the board at 11. o’clock— The bill for amending the districting law had its second reading and pass’d to be engross’d— It was sent down to the house this afternoon— We had the subject of Banks again all this afternoon upon a petition for one in the town of Beverly— It is to be taken up again to-morrow. At the Bankrupt Office this afternoon at 3.— A private meeting in the case of Amos Blanchard. Declared him Bankrupt— Club in the Evening at Dr: Dexter’s. Mr: Ames and Genl: Towne were there— Mrs: Adams and Charlotte Welsh who is with us, went to the play— With Mr: Shaw.— I called in the afternoon at Mr: Gill’s—but he could not see me till to-morrow.

10. Attended at the bankrupt Office, at 9 in the morning, and again at 4. in the afternoon— The remainder of the day at the Senate, which was principally occupied with the subject of Banks— A bill for renewing the Charter of the Union Bank, for 10 years, with some changes, came from the house— Being a proprietor in that bank I took no part in the debate— The Senate struck out two sections, one to tax the bank 5 per cent on the dividends, and the other to take off their obligation to loan upon mortgage— I call’d again upon Mr: Gill, and endeavoured to come to a settlement with him, but we could not agree upon the terms, and we must pursue our remedy at Law. Mrs: Adams and Charlotte Welsh, rode out to Dorchester— Call’d at my Office, and walk’d afterwards in the Mall.

11. At the Bankrupt Office this morning at 9. o’clock, and again at 4. in the afternoon— Remainder of the day at the Senate, where the subject of Banks and of a Statue for Genl: Washington were under discussion— Evening at the Society, where we agreed to adjourn untill the first Thursday in September. Walk’d afterwards with Quincy, a turn in the Mall.

12. Attended at the Senate chamber at 8 this morning upon several Committees— At 10. went to the Bankrupt Office, to a private meeting in the case of W. Allis.— Signed also the first certificate in the case of Robert Dixon. Return’d to the Senate which sat till near 2. At Mr: Gill’s request I sent J. Boylston’s Will to Mr: Sullivan the Attorney-General, to draw up the deeds according to the terms to which Mr: Gill had at length acceded— But Mr: Sullivan sent me back the Will, with some new doubts which he had conceived on perusing the Will— I wrote him an answer, and sent him the Will again— Dined at Mr: Quincy’s, with Judge Pendleton, and his Lady, from New-York, and Judge Davis— Between 6 and 7 in the evening, came out to Quincy, with my wife & child.

13. Bathed after breakfast this morning— Heard Mr: Whitney— Mr: and Mrs: Cranch here at tea; and Deacon French at dinner— Read two treatises of Plutarch; one—how to listen—and the other concerning moral virtue— Wrote a letter to my brother.

14. Return’d to Boston early this morning— Found a letter from Mr: Sullivan: went to his office, and had a conversation of two hours endeavouring to come to an arrangement of the demand upon Gill; but without success— He is determined to carry it through a Court of Law— Attended the Senate debating the Wiscasset Bank bill and other subjects untill 8 this evening.— Walk’d afterwards in the Mall, untill 9.—

15. At the Commission Office, this morning at 10.— 1st: meeting in the case of S. Gookin. Rest of the day at the Senate— Debated and pass’d the Wiscasset Bank-bill— Drew up a new bill for altering the districting Law— They had sent up from the house a new draft, hasty, incorrect, and almost unintelligible. In the afternoon the Senate discuss’d the bill reported, for remitting part of the Sentence on the impeachment of John Vinall. Adjourn’d the decision untill to-morrow— On coming home found Dr: Welsh and his family here— Afterwards I walk’d in the Mall with Mrs: Adams, and Charlotte.

16. Spent the day at the Senate and at the Commission Office. In Senate the bill for remitting a part of J. Vinall’s sentence was debated, and had a first reading, by yeas and nays. 17 to 9.— Third meeting in the case of W. P. Smith, in which a variety of questions arose, of some importance— Quincy called on me at my Office. Went with him to the club at Dr: Elliot’s. Mr: Mitchell of Bridgwater, and Mr: Hayward of Plymouth were there.

17. At the Commission Office this morning at ten— First meeting in the case of William Allis. I had not seen him these six years, and did not immediately recognize him— Drew up some papers this afternoon for Mr: Johnston— The bill to remit Vinall’s punishment in part, pass’d after debate to a second reading. Nearly the whole afternoon was consumed in a debate whether the Courts of Justice in the County of York, should be removed to the town of Alfred— Walk’d in the Mall with Mrs: Adams & Charlotte Welsh.

18. At the Commission Office and at the Senate— Debating in the forenoon upon the report made by the Committee on the late Treasurer’s accounts, and in the afternoon upon the Wiscasset Bank-Bill— Dined at Dr: Dexter’s with a company of sixteen or seventeen Gentlemen— Mr: Sullivan, the Attorney General was there— Walk in the Mall, with Mrs: Adams and Charlotte Welsh; who this Evening went home.

19. At the Commission Office. Case of Benjn: Faxon— Attended the Senate. No debate of material consequence— Sat untill 2. Went with Mr: Gardner Greene to Watertown, where the Assistant fire-club, dined together:—at Vila’s. Return’d to town at about 8 in the evening, and immediately came with J. Gardner out to Quincy. Arrived between 10 and 11 o’clock; and found all the family a-bed.

20. Mr: Otis, the Secretary of the United States Senate with his lady and daughters came out and spent the day here— Heard Mr: Porter of Roxbury with much satisfaction— Bathed this afternoon— Read Plutarch’s treatise, how to distinguish a friend from a flatterer— Captn: Beale & his son Ben. were here in the Evening.

21. Return’d to Boston early this morning. Attended at the Commissioners office at 10 A.M. and again at 4. in the afternoon. Remainder of the day in the Senate— Walk’d in the evening with Mrs: Adams in the Mall— W. Shaw came to live with us.

22. Discuss’d finally the question upon the bill for a Bank at Wiscasset; which with the others this day pass’d in the house of Representatives— Several other debates of little moment. Attended at the Bankrupt office, at 4 this afternoon. Walk’d in the Mall with J. Gardner— Mrs: Johnson and Caroline arrived this evening.

23. The general Court intended to have risen this day, but could not get through with the business. They had various objects of inferior consequence before them— The Senate were chiefly occupied in reading engross’d bills— Spent the evening at Club— Mr: Emerson’s.

24. The Session of the Legislature closed this day— A joint Committee was raised to request a recess of the Governor; and immediately afterwards the Secretary came, and read the titles of all the Acts signed by the Governor, and in his name adjourned the General Court, untill the second Wednesday of January next— Then to meet at 10 o’clock in the forenoon.— Afternoon at my Office and at the Commissioners’ Office— Walk in the Mall; and evening at home.

25. At the Commission Office, at 9 this morning— Second meeting for Saml: Gookin— Mr: Cranch called at my Office in the forenoon— He went to Cambridge to see his sister, and in the evening called again at my house— I spent the day at my Office— Walk’d with Quincy at the beginning of the Evening— Remainder of it, at home. Jos: Hall there—play’d chess with him.

26. Morning at the Commission Office— At 9. 1st: meeting for Philip N. Brown— Mr: Pitts called at my Office— Examined the records of the Common Pleas, upon the business of G. W. M’Intire— My Mother came to town and dined with us— All the ladies went out with her in the afternoon. I went out with J. Gardner.

27. Bathed this morning— Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham, a cousin of the Quincy Minister— Captain Beal’s family to spend the evening— Read Plutarch’s treatise on the government of the temper— Also some of Madame de Sevigne’s letters— Walk on the hill, with my wife.

28. We return’d to Boston this morning, but left Caroline behind— Mr: Babcock called at my office. At the Commissioners Office at 4 p.m. Dined with the Boston light Infantry Company, D. Sargent, Captain—at Concert Hall— Genl: Lincoln, Mr: Dexter, Genl: Elliot and other Officers of the Army & Militia, were there— Afterwards at My Office— And walk’d in the Mall— Evening at home.

29. At the Commission Office this morning— First meeting in the case of Bigelow and Beale— Executed an Assignment to Mr: Gray— All the remainder of the day upon business of my Office— Called at the probate-office— Found Mr: Sullivan was one of the bondsmen for Mr: Gill as Executor of Mr: Boylston— Went with Mr: Pitts to his Office— But after two hours conversation could come to no agreement— Parted wider asunder than ever.— Evening at home— Mrs: Adams unwell.

30. Engaged, great part of the day in Mr: Pitts’s business— At eleven o’clock, attended at the first meeting of the proprietors of Neponset river Bridge— We chose a clerk (W. S. Shaw) and two Committees to view the ground, and to draw up rules and regulations for the corporation. Adjourned to 28 July at 11. A.M.— I dined at T. C. Amory’s, with a small company— At 4 o’clock attended the Commission Office; 3d: meeting for James Campbell— Signed also the first certificate of W. Neal— After the meeting ended I rode out to Roxbury with Jos: Hall— On returning between 7 and 8 I found Mr: Smith and Mr: Pitts at my Office with a new proposition from Mr: Sullivan; which we considered and for which we substituted another for his examination— Went to club at Mr: Kirkland’s— After club, Mr: Smith and myself called again upon Mr: Pitts— It was 11. at night before I got home.

Day. Rise between 5 and 7. Walk about an hour—return and write or read untill 9. Breakfast. During most of the month Attended from breakfast time untill 8 in the evening at the Senate; with the interval of an hour to dine, and of necessary attendance at the bankrupt Office. Since the General Court have risen, I pass the same time at my office— Walk an hour again in the evening, and spend the remainder of it at home— My time is very fully engrossed, but not in a manner satisfactory to myself.
